data.title: Fixed layout of UWP windows in VS template to ignore window chrome.

milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
This fixes the layout to use entire core window on UWP apps.  This helps in particular on Xbox One where it otherwise adds borders around your swap chain to keep the app from the safe zone area (something done manually in games).

Part of the fixes for #4697 .

data.title: `CanDeserializeIntoExistingObject` property is not implemented in readers
data.body: We have the base `CanDeserializeIntoExistingObject` property in `ContentTypeReader`, but it is only overridden in `DictionaryReader`, `ListReader` and `ReflectiveReader` and read in `ReflectiveReader`.

data.title: Automatic building of Content fails in monogame Ouya project (Visual Studio 2015)
data.body:
I am developing on a 64-Bit Windows 10 Home machine in Visual Studio 2015 and I get the following error when I try to build my Ouya test game.

`The command ""C:\Program Files (x86)\MSBuild\MonoGame\v3.0\Tools\MGCB.exe" 
/@:"C:\OuyaTest\Content\Content.mgcb" 
/platform:Ouya 
/outputDir:"C:\OuyaTest\Content\bin\Ouya" 
/intermediateDir:"C:\OuyaTest\Content\obj\Ouya" 
/quiet" exited with code -1.`

I think that the problem is that there is no 'Ouya' platform in the content pipeline to build with.
When I open the content file in the content pipeline and try to select a platform only these show up:
- Android
- DesktopGL
- iOS
- MacOSX
- NativeClient
- Playstation4
- PlaystationMobile
- RaspberryPi
- Windows
- WindowsPhone
- WindowsPhone8
- WindowsStoreApp
- Xbox360

As you can see there is no 'Ouya' platform and the command does try to use it.
Is there maybe a way to alter the command that gets run so that I could build for the 'Android' platform instead of the 'Ouya' one.

data.title: Validate shader parameters in effect compiler
data.body:
As the docu says:

> Make sure the pixel shaders inputs exactly match the vertex shader
> outputs so the parameters are passed in the correct registers.

This could be validated when building the content. E.g. call a ValidateShaderParameters-Method from EffectObject.CompileEffect after ps and vs shader have been created for a pass.

background: http://community.monogame.net/t/xna-effect-port-not-working/1892/12

data.title: Separate out effect and shader reading from effect / shader classes
data.body: This addresses #4678 by allowing effects to be created without relying on the MGFX binary file format.

data.title: Make Mouse Partial Class

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Clean up the `#if`s in the `Mouse` class using partial classes for the various platforms:

https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/Mouse.cs

Please avoid adding features or making functional changes as part of this big refactor.

data.title: Fix Mouse.SetPosition() docs to note platforms where it does not work.
data.body:
We need to add a `<remarks>` section to the docs for `Mouse.SetPosition()` to note which platforms the feature does not work under:

http://www.monogame.net/documentation/?page=M_Microsoft_Xna_Framework_Input_Mouse_SetPosition

I believe this is just the following platforms:
- Web
- Windows 8
- Windows Universal

data.title: Startup crash when speakers are not plugged in
data.body:
I've learned that XAudio device creation fails if there are no speakers plugged into the PC. That is weird... it is like DirectX failing to initialized because there is no monitor plugged in.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35600946/why-oncriticalerror-is-called-in-directx-version-of-xaudio2

Not sure if the OpenAL path suffers from this as well.

MonoGame should be able to internalize this and keep it from being an issue the game developer has to deal with.

data.title: Packed vector tests and fixes
data.body:
Fixes #4685 
This should fix all differences between the Packed Vector classes between XNA and MonoGame. 
The main difference between them was the data ordering, but also that XNA was rounding the values while packaging them, so now the following test is working while previously wasn't

```
// Test packing order.
Assert.AreEqual(0xC7AD8F5C570A1EB8, new Rgba64(0.12f, 0.34f, 0.56f, 0.78f).PackedValue);
```

Apart from the fixes I also did a few upgrades, and in a few cases I replaced the tabs with spaces.

Also `Short2` or `NormalizedShort2` still contains the old license information, should I update it?

data.title: Implemented DynamicSoundEffectInstance for DirectX and OpenAL platforms

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Fixes #4700. This PR adds `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` implementations on XAudio and OpenAL and some unit tests which also run against XNA. I've tested the code on Windows and really quickly on Android. I also hooked it into the iOS platform, but I'm not able to test it at all.

Some issues:
- Thread safety. I've left out any locks etc., but they should be easy to add. I think this code will generate some 1-in-10000 race conditions in multithreaded code.
- Garbage generation. For example #1982 recycled sound buffers, whereas this implementation does not. Should be easy to measure and fix.
- Disposal. I'm able to run the tests without any finalizer/`Dispose()` crashes, but I'm confident that there are issues left.
- ~~I used `nameof`, which is a C# 6 feature. Which language version are we using? Going back to explicit parameter names is a one-minute fix, if we want to support older compiler versions.~~
- ~~OpenAL implementation uses the `DynamicSoundEffectInstanceManager` helper class, which has some issues:~~ (Now shared with all implementations.)
  - ~~It depends on `GamePlatform` calling it. Plugging it into `FrameworkDispatcher` introduced in #4675 would solve that dependency.~~ (Now called by `Game`.)
  - ~~The great SDL change will move things all around the place.~~ (Didn't thanks to above.)
  - ~~It keeps a reference to the playing sound, which has side-effects if the user neither stops nor disposes the sound.~~ (Now holds a `WeakReference`.)
- ~~I know nothing about the Mac side, so I haven't touched it beyond the OpenTK version.~~ (The common SDL path hopefully clears things)
- The tests cannot confirm that the playback actually works, but rather test `PendingBufferCount`.
- And quite possibly many others, which will hopefully be found now that this is up here!

data.title: Consistant Package/Installer Naming
data.body:
I noticed that we're using different naming standards across our packages and installers:

![setupwin](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/14231079/b602912c-f93a-11e5-8b95-427a69157fd4.JPG)

![setupmac](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/14231080/b825b11e-f93a-11e5-87f1-b4f3bc7e0273.JPG)

Seems like we should decide on a convention for naming these things that is consistent across platforms.

@KonajuGames @cra0zy @dellis1972

data.title: Pressing all the way up on a controller stick results in the value flipping to negative

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.title: Render faster if possible on fixed time step
data.body:
Follow up from #2651 with the changes requested.

Currently when MonoGame is using a fixed time step, it won't ever render faster than 60FPS, despite the GPUs capability to do so.

This modifies the tick so that if `RenderMultipleFramesPerStep` is on, it will continue to render frames until the time is used up (instead of sleeping).

This is useful for diagnosing whether rendering is responsible for causing slow frames by giving an accurate representation of how fast the current frame can be rendered.

data.title: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
At least as of 3c3cdb4, I'm getting the following build errors for Xamarin.Mac on my build server:

```

1079    /Users/june/Leases/workingcopy-26971/repo/monogame-upstream/MonoGame.Framework.MacOS.sln (Build) ->
1080    (Build target) ->
1081    /Users/june/Leases/workingcopy-26971/repo/monogame-upstream/MonoGame.Framework/MonoGame.Framework.MacOS.csproj (default targets) ->
1082    /Library/Frameworks/Mono.framework/Versions/4.2.2/lib/mono/xbuild/12.0/bin/Microsoft.CSharp.targets (CoreCompile target) ->
1083    
1084        Graphics/IRenderTarget.cs(102,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1085        Graphics/IRenderTarget.cs(109,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1086        Graphics/RenderTarget2D.OpenGL.cs(28,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1087        Graphics/RenderTarget2D.OpenGL.cs(37,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1088        Graphics/RenderTargetCube.OpenGL.cs(28,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1089        Graphics/RenderTargetCube.OpenGL.cs(37,9): error CS0246: The type or namespace name `TextureTarget' could not be found. Are you missing `OpenTK.Graphics.OpenGL' using directive?
1090    
1091         1 Warning(s)
1092         6 Error(s)
```

I don't know if there were other pull requests that changed render targets for OpenGL recently, but it looks like when that change was made it broke the Xamarin.Mac code path.

data.title: Pipeline tool cannot import fonts

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
Just used Pipeline tool 3.5.1.1679 to build content for my WP8.0 game. Before I was using XNA to build content without any problems.

The Pipeline tool does not seem to import fonts. The font loads in the game but is just displaying the same (I think Ariel) font regardless of font used. Checked the generated xnb file sizes and all the font file sizes are the same.

data.title: Improve Unit Test Performance
data.body:
Since we [added code coverage](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/3820) the unit tests take 5 minutes to run where they used to take under 2 minutes.  This sounds trivial, but if we want to add any more tests and run tests for more platforms like DesktopGL then the testing needs to be as fast as possible.

We are currently running tests on a debug build of the framework so that code coverage has PDB files to work with.  Maybe if we used a debug build with optimization enabled it would improve the run time significantly.

This likely would require building the code a second time specifically for unit testing.  But building the code is literally less than 10 seconds.  It also solves to other issues:
- Smaller build artifact sizes.
- Code coverage will be able to find source code again.
- The test build steps can run in parallel with the code build steps.

This sounds like a win across the board.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release

Remove the old stuff in:

 https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/tree/develop/Tools/MP3Compression

data.title: Improve Unit Test Code Coverage
data.body:
Here is where we currently stand on our code coverage for unit tests:

[Last successful Windows Unit Tests](http://teamcity.monogame.net/viewLog.html?buildTypeId=MonoGame_TestWindows&buildId=lastSuccessful&buildBranch=%3Cdefault%3E&guest=1)

At the time of this writing it looks like this:

![tests](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/103522/14224826/a1b105d0-f86f-11e5-92cf-401eab95806a.JPG)

We need to push the "Statements" metric up to at least 80% in the next few months.  I wrote specific issues for a few major holes:
- [Add Unit Tests for Model Classes](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4699)
- [Add Unit Tests for Effect Classes](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4698)
- [Add Ordering Tests For PackedVector](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4685)
- [Add Unit Tests for Input Classes](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/4744)

Still there are more areas to cover like audio.  Look thru the "Last successful Windows Unit Tests" link above to see which classes are totally untested.

Now code coverage metrics are tricky...  you can get 100% coverage, but do that with crappy tests.  
For example look at this:

 https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/develop/Test/Framework/PackedVectorTest.cs#L85

I wrote most of these tests, but @Tzenchor correctly pointed out in https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/4683 that while I tested for values `<= 0x0` and `>= 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF` I totally missed testing packing order.  So while we had coverage of these areas...  the coverage didn't fully test the feature.

We need to keep this in mind while striving to improve our unit tests.

data.title: What are Pipeline.app and MGCB.app?
data.body:
In the output folders for the Pipeline tool and MGCB I see a Pipeline.app folder and a MGCB.app folder.  These folders seem to have a second copy of the entire tool. See...

 http://teamcity.monogame.net/viewLog.html?buildId=8295&tab=artifacts&buildTypeId=MonoGame_DevelopMac#!111hp1,-a1t0qwm07aky,1qtam4d9dpono

The reason I bring this up is we already have 1GB of artifacts on the Mac/Linux build.  If we are storing artifacts we don't actually use or need that is a huge waste of disk space and performance copying this stuff around.

Do we use these .app folders?  If not how do we keep them from being generated in the first place?

If we do use them... then do we need the first copy of the binaries in the root of the Release folder?

data.title: Implement DynamicSoundEffectInstance and Tests

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
We need to once and for all implement `DynamicSoundEffectInstance` across all platforms.

There was an effort 3 years ago that we were too dumb to get merged:  https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/pull/1982

We should use the ideas from it to help implement the feature for OpenAL and give the skeleton of the feature for XAudio platforms.

Note how the unit tests were written for this.  We should do the same... yes it won't tell us if the audio sounds right, but at least it will catch crashes or state problems.
